speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument this morning in Case 12-9012, Robers v. United States. Mr. Green.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: When you said fully Alderson Reporting Company returned, it wouldn't be fully returned if the debt was greater than the value of the property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, let me just make it clear.  If -- if the loan is for $300,000, fraudulent loan -- fraudulently obtained loan, and the property is foreclosed upon, and it's worth at the time $200,000, is it your position that the property's been fully returned and that there is no liability for the difference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And one more -- one more question. Under Wisconsin law, when there's a foreclosure, is there some automatic valuation ordered by the court or is there an appraiser that automatically is -- is appointed or do we just decide value based on Alderson Reporting Company the bids at the ultimate sheriff's sale?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, I have two related questions. The first is, what your client got was money, and I don't know why it's impossible, impractical or inadequate to measure the loss by the amount he got and order him or her to pay it.  He can pay it on a payment schedule, on any -- in any way that the court wants him to pay it.  So I don't know why we're in (b)(1) or (b)(2) at all because I don't see where the impracticality comes in.  Answer that. But then, secondly, it's not clear to me that we're thinking about this right.  There seems to be no dispute that a loss to the victim is the amount that the victim is spending to sell the property and recoup the money, and you don't seem to be taking issue with that. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And 36 -- 3663(2) appears to be the return of the property at sentencing or sometime thereafter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So it doesn't seem to be controlling earlier return of property, and yet we're sort of stuck in that model that somehow it has to be an either/or.  The earlier date of return or on the date of sentencing.  But shouldn't it be -- and this follows up on Justice Kennedy's question -- shouldn't it be at the time the investor can reasonably secure something from the return of that property, the date of sale? If we're letting them recoup the expenses of sale, why don't we just simply recognize the value on that date?  And if an investor who takes property inadequately decides to hold on to it or -- or with no reasonableness holds on to it or gives it away to their mother or sells it to somebody for a nominal fee, then it should be the date at which they got rid of it or the day -- or the value of the date -- on the date of return or something like that, or the date that they should have done something with the property. Why are we stuck on these -- isn't the whole idea is to make the victim whole?  Don't you make the Alderson Reporting Company victim whole on the day a reasonable investor would have gotten rid of the property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But money is fungible.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that all we're talking -- you know, if I were arguing your side of the case, I Alderson Reporting Company would -- I would not say that the bank got defrauded of money.  Your client never got the money.  The money had to be spent in order to buy the property.  What the fraud here consisted of is that the bank got a -- a loan, a mortgage, an interest in property, assured by a less-than-solvent debtor when it expected to get an interest in property assured by a solvent debtor. And it's -- why isn't the nature of the fraud precisely the mortgage?  This is not as good a mortgage as the bank anticipated it was getting.  And therefore, you don't have to -- it is indeed the very same property.  They -- they gave them back the -- the real estate, but it was not as much as -- as they had expected.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What would happen if it turned out that the property was worth more on the date of sentencing than it was on the date of foreclosure?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, how do you arrive at the foreclosure amount?  I mean, the one virtue or a virtue of the Government's approach is you get the money, and you know exactly how much the house sold for. How do you -- at the time of foreclosure, there's been no sale.  How do you determine the value?  You said in Wisconsin, there are often appraisals, but there wasn't any in this case, was there? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can you answer this -- could you answer, it just happens, not this case, an ordinary case.  Defendants -- defendant goes to Mrs. Smith:  Mrs. Smith, I have a bridge I'd like to sell you.  Wonderful.  Let's go to the account, your account, take out $100,000 and give it to me. She does.        Now, it turns out he didn't own the bridge.  So he owes her $100,000.  Judge:  Pay her $100,000.  Your Honor, I don't have the money with me. Alderson Reporting Company In fact, I don't have it at all.  But I also gave her my valuable Babe Ruth bat.  And I don't have to give her 100,000.  After all, she has the bat.  Okay?  Now, what happens?  I mean, variations on that theme come up every day of the week, I imagine.  What happens?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Not under your theory.  You practice in this area.  I want to know what normally happens.  This is a variation, I imagine, of a very common theme.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, she did.  The bat is on her mantel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Perfect.  And it comes under A, not B?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Wouldn't you say it comes under A, because, after all --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- if -- if he doesn't have the 100,000, does he?  So if you're going to say that Alderson Reporting Company means the fact that he doesn't have it, that he can't return it, and we're under B, what B says to do is pay $100,000.  So you'd end up not being able to read B.  It would be incoherent, I think.  So it must come under A, not B.  I mean, I would have thought so.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They'll read it while -- while I make these criticisms, and then they'll show me on the Government's side, I haven't read it correctly. All right. So but in any case, whatever it comes under, we subtract the value of the bat.  So why don't we do here just what they do there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And is that -- is that how the courts have run this?  I mean, you know, it strikes me as so common that they're supposed to return some money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And, in fact, they will return the money, but it has to be less the value of something that's already been given to those individuals. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I guess it would be up to the judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The judge is not -- there for something, and the judge would, in fact, normally, if she sold the bat, take the -- take the value at the time she sold it.  And there is 90 days he can ask her to sell it.  Your Honor, I don't want to sell it.  I don't want to sell it.  It's a Babe Ruth bat.  Very well, madam.  I will value it for you.  We'll call in an assessor.  That's at least one way I would expect it to work, and I don't understand why it doesn't work that very same way here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's my whole point. That may not make the seller whole.  What makes the seller whole is on the day that he or she sold the item and received money.  That's the Government's point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But -- well, that's not Alderson Reporting Company the Government's point, because the Government wants to value it as of the date of the sentencing.  But the -- but whatever the seller received on the day he or she sold the bat, that's the value that it -- that the seller has put on that item.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Then that's -- that's the question.  That --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, not really.  Not in -- not in this case.  Because in this case, the property was sold.  It was sold late.  But it was not -- it was not -- it was sold before the sentencing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, that was my question earlier, which -- was it reasonable for that seller to hold on to the property that long?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, it doesn't, you just say -- look, "in the case of an offense resulting in the loss of property."  My poor victim lost $100,000.  So that's this case.  Return the property, i.e., return the $100,000, okay?  That's simple.  That's A.  But -- so the judge says, defendant, return 100. Now, let's try -- take B.        If return of the 100 is impossible, say because he's broke, then what are you supposed to do?  Then pay the greater of the value of the property, which is 100,000 on the date of loss or pay the 100,000 on the date of sentencing.  Now, wait. I'm sorry.  That makes no sense.  If you can't pay the 100,000, then what you have to do is pay the 100,000 or pay the 100,000.  I'm sorry. That's why I say that reading it that way to me doesn't make much sense, and therefore, I think this Alderson Reporting Company is a case of A; it is a case where he's simply ordered return the 100,000, and there is implicit in that you don't have to return more than she -- than you took, and you already gave her the bat.  I mean, the bat counts as some kind of a return.  We have to value the bat.  It doesn't tell us what to do.  It's up to the judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh, yes, yes, yes.  It's -- you have to give her 100,000.  It doesn't say anything about what form it has to take.  Our problem is some of it takes the form that isn't cash.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And who's -- who has the burden of proof?  If we -- we know the proceeds when it's sold.  It's not sold.  But you say it has to be valued as of the time of foreclosure.  And I think you Alderson Reporting Company said someplace in your brief that it's the Government's burden to show the value at the time of foreclosure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, the Government's interest, I think, would be to show a low value, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But you say the sentencing judge has to call appraisers?  I mean, valuation of property is the standard stuff of -- of civil proceedings in -- in condemnation and many other cases. You call -- each side calls appraisers.  The appraisers give their -- their judgment and then either the jury or the judge decide.  You want that to happen in every -- in every restitution case like this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I'm not sure a sentencing court is well equipped to do it.  A sentencing court has to call appraisers?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Green, here's one way of looking at this case.  Maybe you'll tell me this is the wrong way of looking at it.  But let's assume that the bank sells the -- the property within a reasonable period of time or as quickly as one could reasonably expect.  So one way of looking at this is which party bears the risk that there is going to be a significant deterioration in the real estate market between the time of foreclosure and the time of sale? Now, your answer to that is that the -- that the victim should bear that risk?  Why should that be? Why would Congress want that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But real estate isn't completely liquid, and so it takes some time to sell it. So between the time when the foreclosure occurs and the time when the victim is able to sell the property and get money, there -- there is a deterioration in the real estate market.  Why should the victim bear that risk?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: That's a completely formalistic answer.  Suppose that the -- what the -- what the person who perpetrated the fraud returns is a truckload of tomatoes.  Very valuable.  It's worth exactly the value of the -- of the original loan.  But very perishable.  And by the time the -- the tomatoes can be sold, they're all rotten.  So they're worth nothing.  And you would say, well, they had dominion and control over the truckload of tomatoes.  What is the difference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That wasn't the hypothetical.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're really confusing me. I -- I -- both the baseball bat and the truckload of tomatoes -- (Laughter.) Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- do not come under B.  I thought that was your case.  Under B, you can deduct the value as of -- as of the date the property is returned, of any part of the property that is returned.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The baseball bat is not a return of part of the property that was stolen.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Nor is the cartload of rotten tomatoes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So what are we talking about here? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why didn't you say that? You were quibbling about when it should be valued.  You should have said it doesn't come under B at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not if it doesn't come into the statute at all. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you agree that if the real property is returned and that everybody agrees that on the day the property is returned, the value is less than the loan amount, that the victim is entitled to the difference between that value and the loan amount?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Then we are under B and then we are talking about money and not the mortgaged property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Money is property.  We're still talking about the value of the loan valued in terms of money and not of the real property, right? Otherwise, your concession that the victim is entitled to the difference can't work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The victim is entitled to the difference in the value of the property and the amount of money stolen based, on your view, on the value of the property at the time that it's returned, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Then we are under B, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Thank you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You made a point about under Wisconsin law, there would be -- and the foreclosure -- suppose there were a foreclosure, there could be no deficiency judgment.  Were you trying to suggest from that that you get the property and -- and no restitution for the rest?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What if I don't think that the -- that the mortgage has anything to do with returning property, that a mortgage -- the real estate is not cash.  Okay?  What if I think it doesn't come under B at all?  How would it be treated if it doesn't come under B?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Cash hasn't been returned. I mean, you could say the same thing about the baseball bat.  He gives him a baseball bat.  It had nothing to do with the cash that he got, and -- and you would say, well, when he sells the baseball bat, he gets cash, therefore cash has been returned.  That's surely not right, is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's the same with the baseball bat, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Ms. Harrington.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What happens if they decide to give the house to -- the banker, to his mother or grandmother?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, no, it doesn't bring into principles.  You -- you have to give -- they took a property that had a value at some point --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- perhaps through the entire period.  What date does the judge use to determine the value of that house?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You're -- you're -- yes, the judge would use his or her discretion and decide what would have been a reasonable value at that -- of that house at a time when the lender should have sold it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Not when they received it, not when the sentencing happened, not after the sentencing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But on the day the court decides whether a reasonable investor who's taken back the property should have converted it to cash.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, it's under -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Exactly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- 3664, which is quite a different thing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's -- that's my point exactly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Ms. Harrington, your whole argument really rests on that statutory language.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And one of the questions that came up in the last half hour is, is that the right Alderson Reporting Company section of the statute.  Now, in your view, which is that the only thing involved here is money, that's all that's involved here, why aren't we under A, rather than B?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Right.  But usually when you don't have money, I mean, say -- let's just say I'm a fraud victim, and I get an order of restitution for $100,000, and the fraudster doesn't have the $100,000. He only has $50,000. So the court says:        Well, now you have to pay the $50,000 and we're going to put you on a schedule of payments, and you are going to pay the other 50 over the next year or two years, whatever.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Would you think that that's under B?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So you think that my hypothetical -- let me -- I'm just -- I'm sorry for -- is under B, not under A?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So any time I don't have enough money to make the victim whole, it's under B, not A?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I don't -- I guess -- gosh, I don't know.  But I would have just thought that it was under A for pretty much the same reason that Justice Breyer said.  It just doesn't make sense for it to be under B.  I mean, essentially you are saying, you know, if -- if -- if return of the cash is impossible, pay the cash under B.  That -- that just doesn't -- that's not a sensible statutory command.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Does it make any difference?  I mean, you know, it's odd to read B as applying because it says if you can't pay back the 100,000, you're -- now we're in B, and what B tells you to do is pay 100,000.  Unless --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You know, I mean, that's what it says.  And then -- and then you have to subtract the amount you already gave, which of course you would have to do anyway.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Return the 100,000.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's just $100,000.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No, but you see if the -- it would make a difference as to whether A or B applies because your whole argument is premised on the language of B. So if we're not in B, if we're in A, your Alderson Reporting Company statutory argument goes away, and then we just try to figure out what offset rules make sense.  I mean, there's got to be an offset in A, too, right?  Suppose we were under A.  It's got to be.  You don't think that there is an offset under A?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Yes, but suppose -- suppose another case. Just say the second half to Justice Breyer. Sorry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, what do you think happens in an A case where let's -- let's -- in a Alderson Reporting Company mortgage case, so there's a home, but this -- this person also has cash and repays the full amount in cash. And now the bank has the full amount in cash, but also has this home.  And then the bank sells the home.  Is -- is the defendant entitled to an offset?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I know.  But if it did arise, because I'm trying to figure out -- it seems to me that there has to be an implicit offset in A as well.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, Ms. Harrington, is it correct this argument that it's all under A?  It has been said that the -- getting to B is based on this idea.  A says if you can't return the property -- if you Alderson Reporting Company can't return the money, B says return the money.  But is that accurate?  What A says is if you don't -- if it's impossible to return the money, assuming that's the thing at issue, B says return the value.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And under 3664, it is possible for the court to order not A, not restitution of money, but restitution of in-kind services.  So there can be -- value can be conveyed in a form other than money, so it isn't circular, is it, in the way that's been suggested?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If you want to read it that way, it's the same problem.  It seemed redundant, not circular.  But you don't think it's redundant, okay. Fine.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The same problem is there. You go to 3664, and what happened was it says in 3664: Enter a restitution order, judge.  And when you do that, Alderson Reporting Company provide for a lump-sum payment or partial payments or at specified intervals, in-kind payments, a combination of payments.  It gives a judge a lot of discretion. So I imagine the judge, if he'd already given her back 20,000, would say:  Now, defendant, pay her $80,000 more.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, the problem here is, instead of giving her the $20,000, he gave her an in-kind payment.  You see, he gave her a baseball bat or in this case a house.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And so now our question is how do we value the house, and the statute doesn't tell us.  Since that's so, I would have thought -- you have a very good point -- if, as here, the victim has sold the house already, well, what he got for it?  That's the end of that.  Unless, of course, it was an unreasonable, fraudulent, or hooked-up sale, which the defendant can point out, and the judge could -- what happens if she won't sell the house?  She says:  I love the bat, I love the house, I'm not selling. Then you say you have 90 days to do it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- or you -- or let it Alderson Reporting Company befall on you what help befalls.  And then what you have to do is value the house if she still won't sell it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And you have to value the bat if she still won't sell it.  Do I have that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: MS. HARRINGTON: property --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: they're try to get rid of.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But it also goes back to how do you measure and when do you measure this. It's easy if the property is returned on the date of Alderson Reporting Company sentencing or 90 days after, or not returned then. Because then the judge could basically figure out what's a reasonable time, the date of sentence or within the 90 days, the day they sold the property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But -- but the question becomes what happens when the house is done before -- given over not as a part of sentencing, but independently.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And that -- and that's why I don't think any of these provisions really answer that question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And so why don't we go back to the basics?  Why should the victim -- I think you agree with this -- why should the victim suffer the loss attendant to selling property that decreases in value because during the time that they were teeing it up for sale, the market dropped, and you say the victim shouldn't. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But let's assume that the market dropped and they sold it.  What's the value you give to the -- to the victim?  It's the date that the victim sold the property, no?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Now, Justice Breyer asked you what happens if on some day, they did something unreasonable.  They just kept the property. They gave it to a grandmother.  They sold it to someone for a nominal amount.  A sham transaction.  What does a judge do then?  They kept the property because they just didn't want to sell it.  They just let it die because they were lazy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Is that a case the victim should be made whole for their loss?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you agree that the victim, in this case the bank, may not hold on to the property for an unreasonable period of time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There wasn't -- there wasn't anything at all in the record to suggest that there was undue -- that that 33 months was an undue Alderson Reporting Company delay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And there's a question about this case that I would like you to answer before you finish.  And this is a case of a young man, 19 years old, he gets hooked into this scheme.  He gets $500 for each parcel, $1,000; and then he's ordered to make restitution of $219,000.  He was a bit player in the scheme.  What happened to the people who dreamed up this scheme, Lytle and Valadez?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So that -- but did they -- were they ordered to pay restitution for these two houses?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I think I understand now better than I did what his argument is.  I see now why you want to go from A, because there are all kinds of property that could be taken, not just money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And they say now A is out of it because he wasn't able to return it, so we're in B.  And I was saying well, B requires the same thing; and you say that's right.  So what's the point?  Well, you say but that's how it works for other property, anyway. Now, when we get to B, we get that last phrase, and they want to make like doubly sure that -- that if in fact some of the property had already been gone back, it's going to count; and he's saying, well, it did go back.  It was in-kind, the baseball bat or the house, and he's saying now, how do we value that?  And you say, well, let's value it the same way as we would value in-kind property were there a list -- is that right -- of 3664?  And -- and you then go on to say, the simplest thing to do is if they -- they should sell it. And then I say, okay, maybe they should, but they don't want to.  And then what do we do?  And the answer is call in experts like he wants.  Now, have I got that Alderson Reporting Company right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Thank you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh, I'm not sure you'd say no part of the property they lost has been returned.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What's been happening is they've got some in-kind return.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's true.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And when they sell and they get much more money than they otherwise thought from the house, that extra amount also counts, then, in the defendant's favor?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, how does the defendant get the benefit of that?  What would the defendants do to go get the excess?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You would agree that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Over the -- the total amount lost?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You would -- you would -- you would agree that a different rule applies if there is some unreasonable delay in disposing of the property?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And what do you do in the case of some dramatic development between the return of the house as opposed to the -- the property and its -- and its sale?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you know, something is discovered with respect to the property that nobody knew about.  It's -- suddenly, it's a hazardous chemical zone and the property is -- is worthless.  While when it was returned -- not returned; I don't mean to prejudge the case.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: When the bank got it, it was worth $200,000, but all of a sudden it's, you know, Love Canal or something, and it's worth nothing.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, no.  But my point is, is it the value you could sell it for before this discovery of an extraordinary condition, or is it the value afterward?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, what if they get -- they get the house and as soon as they get it, there are ten offers at $500,000 or more, and the amount of the restitution is, you know, $300,000 or whatever. But the bank says, you know, I think the market is going to go even higher, so I'm not going to sell it right away, I'm going to wait, not an unreasonable length of time, but I'm going to wait.  And then the market craters.  I mean, is the same rule then, that they only get what they were able to sell it for?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I know banks like to get rid of property as soon as possible, but, you know, they make decisions at some point, let's wait before we sell this.  Is that commercially reasonable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, why should the defendant here subsidize the banks playing the market? That's what you are saying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The bank is playing the market.  It says, yeah, we could sell it for so much now, but, yeah, it may go up.  And you're saying that, you know, he's paying for the bank's roll of the dice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But if I could just be clear about what you're saying, you're saying it's not the sale price when the sale is for a nominal amount; is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And it's not the sale price if the lender has done something commercially unreasonable? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And so if that's right and both of those things sound right, but why doesn't that kind of explode your statutory argument, because then it's not any part of the property that's returned.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I followed you up through here, I think.  You're into B.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He is pointing to little (ii) and you're saying that really is not relevant here because it's cash.  None of the property was returned; they gave him a house, not the cash.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, right.  What they have is the house.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh, I see.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And that is if they've sold it before the sentencing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, let's suppose it doesn't and they still have it as of the time of sentencing, then we're over into 3(a).  It's an -- 3664.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's an in-kind payment. The judge has discretion as to how to value it.  He could say, sell it within 90 days, and we will take that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or he could say if you don't want to do that, we call in the assessors.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You're saying because (3)(ii) applies, that when it's transformed into cash prior to the sentencing, then they have received --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So where do you value for the person who -- the -- the creditor, the secured creditor who acts unreasonably? Let's assume an unreasonable act, and you said it might have been commercially unreasonable to hold on to the property after somebody offered them twice the amount of their mortgage. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- what do you think of this test?  In calculating a creditor's loss resulting from a secure transaction, the restitution order -- award should be offset by the amount that a reasonably diligent creditor, under the same or similar circumstances, could or would -- or did -- could, would or did obtain for the collateral?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it's not just more complicated.  It's a question of, I guess, who has the burden.  As I understood, what you are proposing is you get the sale price, but it's -- it's available to the defendant to show that the sale price was unreasonably low because of gamesmanship on the part of the bank or some other reason, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You would prefer that to the other formulation, wouldn't you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If the sale -- if at the time of sentencing, the house has not yet been sold, but there's no -- there's good reason for the delay, because for example, there are no bids at an earlier time, could the judge defer the restitution order until the house is sold?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What does the defendant do if they act unreasonably after that order?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If the bank does a Alderson Reporting Company nominal sale and only gets $100?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Green, you have 5 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why not?  Why not just say, hey, I'll tell you what happened here.  They -- we gave him a house worth 100,000, and they sold it for a dollar, and they only want to subtract a dollar, the Government.  But I will tell you something.  I would count that house as an in-kind payment --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- an in-kind payment, and they were wrong to sell it.  And it was worth 100,000, that was totally crooked, their selling it.  And therefore, I want you to say, fine, perfectly right subtract $1 under (ii) -- (ii), but subtract 99,000 more because of the in-kind payment that was made. Would you say that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but the only reason he would have been trespassing is because, in fact, he did not live in the house as he promised the bank he would when the bank gave him the money.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So why shouldn't he bear the responsibility for that consequence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There was no -- there was no -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- evidence of that in this case, that the bank held on too long.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The answer that Ms. Harrington gave was that there were no bids.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I think she said there were no bids.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Is there any reason why the -- why the sentencing judge, where there's an -- an allegation and maybe a -- a suggestion that there was unreasonable delay or something unreasonable was going Alderson Reporting Company on require the Government to provide some substantiation for -- for what happened?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. The case is submitted.
